RFK built a national reputation by acting as Joe McCarthy's lead counsel and his brother's AG, also winning a senate seat before his fateful run for office. What has Beto done? Six years on the El Paso City Council and 6 years in the House, as a backbencher. And Buttigieg may have administrative experience because of his 8 year mayorship of South Bend, that's all he has. Several years in the army reserve; went in as a lieutenant, went out as a lieutenant doesn't sound like a bucketful of ambition. Neither one is ready for anything nearly as important as the presidency.

title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: This is what really matters here: "The record of the past 50-plus years is irrefutable: Whenever the party has nominated a former vice president (Hubert Humphrey in 1968, Walter Mondale in 1984, Al Gore in 2000) or a similar figure of long exposure to the public eye, such as Hillary Clinton in 2016, he or she has fallen short. The same has been the case with policy-oriented liberals like George McGovern in ‚Äô72 and Michael Dukakis in ‚Äô88." In other words: In most instances, the more the public sees a Democrat actually doing policy, and the more familiar they are with the person over time, the less they like him/her. I actually predicted this when Hillary announced her run. I knew enough people in exactly the right states liked the _idea_ of Hillary way more than they were going to like the reality, and the more they saw of her, the more they were not going to be able to stand her. And that's exactly how it turned out. So why is this, exactly, if the author's thesis and its corollaries are correct, which I think they mostly are? What does it mean that people like the "feel" they get from somebody like O'Rourke, or Bill Clinton, or whoever? (At least Clinton had run a state. I'm not making a comparison on the merits, experience, etc., here.) And what does it mean that they play into that "feel" and away from the details? What kind of voters respond to that sort of thing? What does that say about the party?

title: The Last Time a President Got a Pass on a Scandal-Plagued White House Magazine
content: Sometimes, when I think of Herbert Hoover, I feel bad for him that an economic crisis that should have been blamed upon Coolidge came to be blamed upon him. After the Wall Street Crash and the ensuing depression, Hoover had no chance of success as Presdient. But then I remember Hoover's role in the Coolidge Administration: As the effective Economic Czar. Back then, as today, the Treasury Secretary traditionally had the most economic influence in the Cabinet. Interesting, back then - due to the huge number of people who lived on farms - the Agriculture Secretary was the 2nd most influencial economic Cabinet Secretary. But Coolidge broke tradition by coming to rely most on Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover. Whenever an economic issue or decision reared its head, Coolidge went to Hoover . Since Coolidge is quite possibly our laziest President, Hoover operated with much autonomy. The Coolidge economy, with all if its fragility, was Hoover's economy. Once I remind myself of that, I am less charitable toward Hoover vis-a-vis the Great Depression. The economy that imploded while Hoover was Presdent,was - in significant part - Hoover's economy.
